messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re: 18 and 21 year olds who were unschooled
messages.msgSnippet: I went to ps, but I wasn t ready for college until I was 26.  When I felt ready to go, I enjoyed it, applied myself, and finished with a great GPA (for
messages.messageBody:
I went to ps, but I wasn't ready for college until I was 26. When I felt
ready to go, I enjoyed it, applied myself, and finished with a great GPA
(for whatever that is worth) Also, from age 19 to 25, I was LIVING,
rather than go from high school to college to full-time job.
Mary Ellen
snip>>>>>>>>>>I am worried he will give up his music and be a dry waller
just because he is afraid to go to school! I wonder sometimes how to get
them out of their comfort zone and try something new and challenging

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re: 18 and 21 year olds who were unschooled
messages.msgSnippet: Kasie, I gently refer you to your own signature line. Maybe some time away will help him see if music is really what he wants to do? There is no law that says
messages.messageBody:
Kasie, I gently refer you to your own signature line. Maybe some time away
will help him see if music is really what he wants to do? There is no law
that says he can't start a year later if he changes his mind.
Johanna
Life is the ultimate learning experience!
----- Original Message -----
From: "Kasie" <mrscalgal@...>
To: <Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, August 31, 2001 1:11 PM
Subject: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re: 18 and 21 year olds who were unschooled


>
> 18 and 21 year olds who were unschooled.Please share what they do now!
>
> My son 17 is working as an apprentice doing dry wall with my friends
husband. He says he would rather do that than go to college. So we did not
force him to go and take the music classes he had previously chosen. I know
he likes music more than doing dry wall we have talked about that in the
past. I am worried he will give up his music and be a dry waller just
because he is afraid to go to school! I wonder sometimes how to get them out
of their comfort zone and try something new and challenging!
>
>
>
>
>
> "Do not worry about anything, but in everything by prayer
> and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be
> made known to God." Philippians 4.6

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re: 18 and 21 year olds who were unschooled
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 08/31/2001 6:20:11 PM !!!First Boot!!!, ... Maybe he will go to college in a few years and get something out of it (after learning that
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 08/31/2001 6:20:11 PM !!!First Boot!!!,
mrscalgal@... writes:


> I am worried he will give up his music and be a dry waller just because he
> is afraid to go to school! I wonder sometimes how to get them out of their
> comfort zone and try something new and challenging!
>
>
>
>
>
>

Maybe he will go to college in a few years and get something out of it (after
learning that being a dry waller isn't all it's cracked up to be!) -- unlike
my going to college when it was the "right" time and completely blowing it!

Maybe he'll start his own construction biz.

Maybe he'll do something completely different.

Maybe he'll change his mind several times.

Maybe he'll find a way to pursue his music without going to school.

Nance



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re: 18 and 21 year olds who were unschooled
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 8/31/01 12:20:11 PM Mountain Daylight Time, ... But he s doing something real, and learning drywalling (and other construction stuff, no
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 8/31/01 12:20:11 PM Mountain Daylight Time,
mrscalgal@... writes:


> ! I wonder sometimes how to get them out of their comfort zone and try
> something new and challenging!
>

But he's doing something real, and learning drywalling (and other
construction stuff, no doubt) without having to pay for the privilege! Where
are most of the other 17 year olds?

Why would having a daytime job hinder music? There are LOTS more hours in
the week than 40.

I figure if Kirby's job becomes full time and he gets complacent in a
low-paying job, he would either get tired of it, or get a girlfriend he
wanted to impress and that would be a real biological reason for him to work
to advance himself financially.

Sandra


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: 18 and 21 year olds who were unschooled
messages.msgSnippet: 18 and 21 year olds who were unschooled.Please share what they do now! My son 17 is working as an apprentice doing dry wall with my friends husband. He says he
messages.messageBody:
18 and 21 year olds who were unschooled.Please share what they do now!

My son 17 is working as an apprentice doing dry wall with my friends husband. He says he would rather do that than go to college. So we did not force him to go and take the music classes he had previously chosen. I know he likes music more than doing dry wall we have talked about that in the past. I am worried he will give up his music and be a dry waller just because he is afraid to go to school! I wonder sometimes how to get them out of their comfort zone and try something new and challenging!





"Do not worry about anything, but in everything by prayer
and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be
made known to God." Philippians 4.6

messages.subject: 18 and 21 year olds who were unschooled
messages.msgSnippet: Susan has very amazing daughters.  Please tell us what they re doing if you re willing and have
messages.messageBody:
<< I have two daughters, 18 and 21.

Susan (hiya, Sandra!) >>

Susan has very amazing daughters. Please tell us what they're doing if
you're willing and have the energy. There are people here could use the
inspiration of some musical, artistic, imaginative, goodhearted homeschooled
teens!

(I met Susan when my husband was working in Minneapolis for six months... a
year... a year and a half... two years. We got to see each other a few
times. It was wonderful to see her girls getting older. And they visited
Albuquerque once.)

Sandra

"Everything counts."
http://expage.com/SandraDoddArticles
http://expage.com/SandraDodd
